p.s: The Sonnet 60 by William Shakespeare is about how the lyrical I talks about time and actions and about their dependancy of each other.
The lyrical I also mentions examples for it and reflects it on his or her life.
This sonnet was probably published around the late 16th century or at the beginning of the 17th century.
This sonnetssonnet's structure contains three quatrains and at the end a couplet.

The metrum of this sonnet is iambic pentameter and it is firstly about how the lyrical I illustrates to his addressed person that their time has come to an end so do our minutes hasten to their end (l. 2) and it seems to justify it by saying each is changing with mostly what was before Each is changing place with that which goes before (l. 3).
In the second quatrain the lyrical I gives an example of how time change affects your doing.
He uses the example of Jesus Christ, who raises up and just receivereceives admiration, but was then betrayed, so he was no longer beloved by the people and starts to fall.
In the couplet, the lyrical I praises that there are now hopeful times, although not everything seems to go right for the lyrical I Praising thy worth, despite his crual hand (l. 14).
Now to analyze the language of this sonnet it begins witha simile already in the first two lines.
The lyrical I comapres floating waves towards a pebbled shore with the lasting minutes between it and its addresseaddressee.
It does that also to metaphorize that the high tide is now over and the low tide begins.
So after the minutes end between the lyrical I and its addresseaddressee the tide is our in their relationship.
In general illustrates this particular sonnet the worth of time.
It is the main topic it also gets different perspectives.

At first, it is about time in a relationship with somebody, then it is viewed as the cause of a downfall and in the end it is illustrated to bring hope and stamina across an also brutal time at that moment.
Another wordfieldword field which is, compared to the first wordfieldword field about time, more indirect, it also involves time, but in a certain aspect.
It is about how progressive time can affect a person.
About how people change an through that the loss in interest e.g. in a person change their sanity and now they might fight against mental issues or even death.
But now I want to focus back on the analysis of the language.
In line 3 each changing place with that which goes before, shows the perspective of the lyrical I about changes.
It views it like it is always going in circles and that there is no opportunity that it changes this time differently.
The only way how it might not go in circle is when you put hard work into it that it will go forward.
In sequent toil all forwards do contend(l. 4) means that you have to do something actively against it, otherwise it will remain the same over and over again.
The second quatrain contains an example of how time can affect somebody.
The lyrical I uses this illustration of the life of Jesus Christ to underline his opinion of the cruel influence of time.
He firstly emphasizes the appearance of Jesus Christ together with his rise.
Nativity, once in the main of light(l. 5).
He creates this image of the Chosen One by not saying he was born in Nativity to very poor parents in a stable somewhere between Egypt and Israel.

By saying, once in the main of light and going on crawls to maturity, wherewith being crowned (l. 4) the lyrical I uses a hyperbole of JesusJesus' development just to create a greater contrast in the following lines of this quatrain.
Crooked exclipses 'gainst his glory fight, And time that gave doth now his gift confound(l. 7-8).
This underlines the statements about affection of time by the lyrical I.
By using his glory fight and his gift (l. 3-4), the lyrical I justifies or puts a positive light on the actions and opinions of Jesus Christ to keep up this contrast.
It even uses the word glory (l. 3), so the lyrical I makes his fight sacred and through that no one would ever believe that he has done bad things to provide himself.
In the third quatrain the lyrical I goes on that time has a major influence on development.
Time doth transfix the fourish set on youth(l. 9) shows that the lyrical I again creates a constrast by telling that time transfixes a lovely, flourish set on youth.
It emphasizes the beauty of the flourish set just to get transfixed by time.
Also using the word transfix shows that the lyrical I tries to persinificate time to bring the impact of time closer to the reader by the use of a human action that everyone is familiar with.
This goes on in the next verse: And delves the parallels in beauty brow (l. 10).
It starts with an enjambement from line 9 to line 10 to connect the two mentioned actions caused by time.
It again reproaches time to take something away.
This time it takes away the beauty facial expressions, which the lyrical I is heavily searching.
That is why these lines are connected and not seperatedseparated as the rest of this poem, because they share the same topic about reproach.
Line 11 Feeds on the rarities of nature's truth, shows that the mentioned person lives minimalistic and just has not a lot of things.
And everything gets taken from him.
And nothing stands but for his scythe to mow(l. 12) shows this point of the lyrical I either.
These two verses are seperatedseparated and do not belong together through an enjambement, but they both portrait the same umage and symbol.

The concerned person the lyrical I talks about is at first a symbol who stands for a low possession of matreliasticmaterialistic things, who still gets taken everything he has, doesn't matter how much he possesses.
The imagery begins with mentioning but for his scythe to mow (l. 12).
This illustrates the image better due to mentioning he only has left one thing.
And this scythe symbolizes the now even cruel poverty he has to go through.
The last two lines of sonnet 60 reverse the image of the lyrical I.
Then in the couplet the lyrical I starts talking about positive aspects time brings within.
That you can achieve hope during a tough time and appreaciating the worthiness of the poeple around.
This contrast gets illustrated in line 14: Paising thy worth, descpite his cruel hand.
By using the word despite the lyrical I wants his readers to know that these two things are connected.
With that he creates this contrast, but leaves this sonnet with a dark personification of the times he lives in, although he or she now sees the positive affects of time with hope and love.
All in all this sonnet by Shakespeare shows how talented he was at writing.
In 14 lines he created a whole story, where you discover or understand new things, although it is the second or third time you are reading it.
You get immediately fascinated through the beauty of words and the imagery they come along with.
